```{r combine data functions, include=FALSE}

convert_population <- function(tbl, value){
  tbl |> 
    as_tibble() |> 
    pivot_longer(
      matches("\\d{4}"), names_to = "year",
      values_to = value
    ) |> 
    mutate(
      year = as.numeric(year)
    )
}


combine_datasets <- function(data_sets, join_by){
  
  pop_forecast = NULL
  for (i in 1:length(data_sets)) {
    
    dataset_name <- 
      names(data_sets)[i]
    
    table_converted <- 
      data_sets[[i]] |> 
      convert_population(dataset_name)
    
    if (is.null(pop_forecast)) {
      pop_forecast <- 
        table_converted
    } else {
      pop_forecast <- 
        full_join(
          pop_forecast, table_converted, 
          by = join_by
        )
    }
  }
  
  return(pop_forecast)
}

iso_to_unicode_flag <- function(iso2c) {
  sapply(iso2c, function(code) {
    if (is.na(code)) return(NA)
    paste0(
      intToUtf8(127462L + which(LETTERS == substr(code, 1, 1)) - 1L),
      intToUtf8(127462L + which(LETTERS == substr(code, 2, 2)) - 1L)
    )
  })
}

```

```{r get raw data download, include=FALSE}
fertility_rate_plot_data <- 
  fertility_rate |> 
  filter(iso2c %in% c("AM", "AZ", "GE", "RU", "TR", "IR")) |> 
  mutate(
    country = case_when(
      country == "Russian Federation" ~ "Russia",
      TRUE ~ country
    ),
    linewidth_marker = ifelse(iso2c %in% c("AM"), "Armenia", "Others"),
    flag = iso_to_unicode_flag(iso2c),
    country = countrycode(iso3c, origin = "iso3c", destination = "cldr.name.hy"),
    country_label = ifelse(year == min(year), paste(country, flag), NA)
  )

  fertility_rate_plot_data |> filter(year == min(year)) |> 
  arrange(desc(fertility)) |> pull(country)
```

```{r, include=FALSE}

fertility_factor_data <- 
  tibble(
    fertility = seq(0.8, 3, 0.1)
  ) |>
  mutate(
    gen1_decline = -(1 - fertility/2.1),
    gen2_decline = -(1 - (fertility/2.1)^2),
    gen3_decline = -(1 - (fertility/2.1)^3),
    gen3_decline = gen3_decline - gen2_decline,
    gen2_decline = gen2_decline - gen1_decline,
  ) |> 
  pivot_longer(
    contains("decline"), 
    names_to = "generation",
    values_to = "decay"
  ) |> 
  mutate(
    generation = ifelse(
      fertility >= 2.1,
      str_replace(generation, "decline", "growth"),
      generation
    ),
    generation = fct_inorder(generation),
    generation = fct_rev(generation),
    direction = str_remove(generation, "^gen\\d_"),
    direction = ifelse(fertility == 2.1, NA, direction)
  )

plot_fertility_factor <- 
  fertility_factor_data |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = fertility, y = decay)) +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 0, color = new_palette_colors[1]) +
  geom_col(
    aes(fill = generation),
    alpha = 1, position = position_stack()) +
  geom_text(aes(
    y = 0, label = ifelse(fertility == 2.1, NA, fertility), 
    vjust = case_when(
      direction == "growth" ~ 1.4,
      direction == "decline" ~ -0.4,
      TRUE ~ 0.5
    )
  )) +
  geom_text(
    data = tibble(x = 0.765, y = 0.3, label = "Births per Woman"),
    mapping = aes(x, y, label = label),
    hjust = 0, fontface = "bold"
  ) +
  geom_segment(
    data = tibble(x = 2.1, y = 0, xend = 2.1, yend = 1.7),
    aes(x, y, xend = xend, yend = yend),
    color = new_palette_colors[1], linetype = 2
  ) +
  geom_text(
    data = tibble(x = 2.05, y = 1.6, label = "2.1 երեխա 1 կնոջից\nհավասարակշռության կետ"),
    aes(x, y, label = label),
    color = new_palette_colors[1], hjust = 1,
  ) +
  geom_text(
    data = tibble(x = 2.07, y = c(-0.72, -0.88), label = c("անկում", "աճ")),
    aes(x, y, label = label),
    color = new_palette_colors[1], hjust = 1,
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(
    breaks = seq(-1, 2, 0.2),
    labels = scales::percent_format(),
  ) +
  scale_fill_manual(
    values = colfunc2(16)[c(2,4,6,10,12,14)],
    labels = c("3-րդ սերունդ", "2-րդ սերունդ", "1-ին սերունդ", "3-րդ սերունդ", "2-րդ սերունդ", "1-ին սերունդ")
  ) +
  labs(
    x = NULL,
    y = NULL,
    fill = NULL,
    title = "Population Decay Per Generation",
    subtitle = "Population Decline",
    caption = caption_f()
  ) +
  guides(fill = guide_legend(reverse = TRUE, byrow = TRUE)) +
  theme(
    panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(), 
    panel.grid.major.y = element_line(
      colour = "gray", linewidth = 0.1,
      linetype = 1
    ),
    axis.text.x = element_blank(),
    legend.position = "inside",
    legend.position.inside = c(0.75, 0.092),
    legend.background = element_blank()
  )
```


## [Armenia's Population Crisis: Heading Towards 2 Million by 2100](https://www.tvyal.com/newsletter/2024/2024_11_04)

Armenia faces a critical demographic challenge that will reshape its future. Current projections show that by 2100, Armenia's population could shrink to just 2 million people - a dramatic decline that threatens the country's economic and social fabric. Let's dive into the data to understand what's driving this trend and what it means for Armenia's future.

In the long run, only two fundamental factors determine a country's economic growth potential: its future population and improvements in energy infrastructure. While we've covered Armenia's energy challenges and opportunities in our recent analysis [🔌⚡🇦🇲 էլեկտրիկ Հայաստան․ Ցանցի խոցելիությունից մինչև արևային հեռանկարներ](https://www.tvyal.com/newsletter/2024/2024_09_09), today we'll focus on the demographic challenges that could fundamentally reshape Armenia's future.

Գծապատկեր 1

[![](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/tavad/tvyal_newsletter/refs/heads/main/2024/2024_11_04_population/plots/plot_arm_population_forecast.png)](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/tavad/tvyal_newsletter/refs/heads/main/2024/2024_11_04_population/plots/plot_arm_population_forecast.png)


The graph above shows Armenia's historical population trends and future projections. While neighboring countries like Azerbaijan have seen population growth, Armenia's trajectory points downward. This decline isn't just about numbers - it represents a fundamental shift in Armenian society that will affect everything from economic growth to national security.

Կանխատեսված միտումը հիմնված է մինչև 2019թ. գրանցված տվյալների հիման վրա: Կանխատեսման մեջ հաշվի առնված չեն 2020 թվականի 44-օրյա Արցախյան պատերազմի, 2023 թվականի Արցախի կորուստի և որպես հետևանք արցախահայության արտագաղթի, ինչպես նաև ռուս-ուկրաինական հակամարտության հետևանքով Ռուսաստանի Դաշնությունից մոտ 100-140 հազար ռելոկանտների Հայաստան տեղափոխվելու, և վերջին երկու տարիների ընթացքում համեմատաբար մեծ քանակությամբ Հնդկաստանի քաղաքացիների՝ Հայաստան ներգաղթի հանգամանքները: ՌԴ 100-140 հազար քաղաքացիների ներգաղթը կազմում է Հայաստանի բնակչության 3-4 տոկոսը: ՌԴ ռելոկանտների զգալի մասը հայ է: Նշենք, որ [ըստ նախկին էկոնոմիկայի նախարարի, ռելոկանտների մոտ մեկ երրորդ մասը արդեն 6 ամիս առաջ լքել էր Հայաստանը](https://arm.sputniknews.ru/20240203/inchu-en-relvokantnery-heranum-hhic-pattsharneri-masin-khvosum-en-henc-irenq-ev-pvordzagetnery-71585615.html): Այս զգալի փոփոխությունները դեռևս հաշվի չեն առնված այս կանխատեսման մեջ: Սա որոշ չափով կարող է մեղմել ժողովրդագրական խնդիրը:

Ընդգծենք նաև, որ Հայաստանում արդեն հաստատվել են մեծ քանակությամբ Հնդկաստանի քաղաքացիներ: Հնդկաստանից հիմնականում եկել են արական սեռի ներկայացուցիչներ՝ առանց իրենց ընտանիքների: Անհրաժեշտ է ուսումնասիրություն կատարել՝ պարզելու, թե ինչ ժամանակահատվածով են Հնդկաստանից եկած տղամարդիկ պլանավորում մնալ Հայաստանում և մշակել համապատասխան քայլեր՝ նրանց Հայաստանում լիարժեք ինտեգրման համար:


### Understanding the Core Issue: Fertility Rates

The key to understanding population decline lies in the fertility rate - the average number of children born to each woman. For a population to remain stable, this number needs to be about 2.1 children per woman (called the replacement rate). Why 2.1 and not simply 2? The extra 0.1 accounts for several real-world factors: some children may not survive to adulthood, some may not have children of their own, and some may emigrate. This subtle difference is crucial for maintaining population stability.

However, Armenia's current fertility rate is just 1.6 children per woman, well below what's needed to maintain the population.

[![](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/tavad/tvyal_newsletter/refs/heads/main/2024/2024_11_04_population/plots/plot_fertility_change.png)](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/tavad/tvyal_newsletter/refs/heads/main/2024/2024_11_04_population/plots/plot_fertility_change.png)


This chart shows how fertility rates have changed in Armenia and neighboring countries over time. The trend is clear: Armenia, like many of its neighbors, has seen a steady decline in birth rates. However, there are important regional differences:

* Azerbaijan maintained higher fertility rates through the 1990s and 2000s
* Georgia shows similar patterns to Armenia but with slightly different timing
* Turkey's demographic transition has been more gradual

### Ժողովրդի անկման հաշվարկ: A Generational Impact

Գծապատկեր 3

[![](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/tavad/tvyal_newsletter/refs/heads/main/2024/2024_11_04_population/plots/plot_fertility_factor.png)](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/tavad/tvyal_newsletter/refs/heads/main/2024/2024_11_04_population/plots/plot_fertility_factor.png)

This chart reveals the mathematical reality of population decline over generations. With Armenia's current fertility rate of 1.6:

* First generation (25-30 years): 23.8% decline
* Second generation (50-60 years): 41.9% decline
* Third generation (75-90 years): Even more severe decline

To put this in perspective:
Starting with 1000 people at current fertility rates:

* By 2050: Down to 762 people
* By 2080: Further down to 581 people
 * By 2100: Continuing decline

This compounding effect explains why small changes in fertility rates can have such dramatic long-term impacts on population size.

### The Real Impact on Armenia's Economy

A shrinking population hits the economy in ways many don't expect. When the workforce shrinks, companies struggle to find skilled workers. This leads to higher wages - which might sound good at first, but it can make Armenian businesses less competitive globally.

Innovation suffers too. With fewer young entrepreneurs entering the market, there's less fresh thinking and fewer new businesses. A smaller domestic market means local businesses have fewer customers, making it harder to grow and compete.

The government faces its own challenges. Fewer workers mean less tax revenue, yet the cost of maintaining roads, schools, and other infrastructure stays the same - or even increases per person. This creates a difficult balance: how to provide the same services with less money?

### The Healthcare System Under Pressure

As Armenia's population ages, our healthcare system faces mounting pressure. We're seeing a sharp increase in the need for elderly care, while having fewer young workers to pay into the healthcare system.

Hospitals and clinics need to adapt. They must shift their focus from general care to managing chronic conditions and elderly care. This means new training for medical staff and different types of medical facilities - all while working with a smaller tax base.

### The Pension Problem

The math is simple but concerning: fewer workers supporting more retirees isn't sustainable. Today's pension system was designed for a younger population, but that reality is changing fast.

This isn't just about numbers - it's about real people. How do we ensure our elderly can live with dignity when there are fewer workers contributing to the pension system? This question demands urgent attention and creative solutions.

### Beyond Economics: National Security and Culture

A declining population affects Armenia's ability to maintain a strong defense force. In a region where security challenges persist, this demographic shift could have serious implications for national security.

Our cultural heritage faces challenges too. With fewer young people, it becomes harder to keep traditional customs, languages, and arts vibrant and alive. Small communities, particularly in rural areas, may struggle to maintain their local traditions and institutions. There is a high chance that to keep the carrent demand and economic growtht the workforce and population will be replaced with the imigrants, from asia and africa, which have fartility rates above 4.

### What Can Be Done?

Some countries have found ways to address these challenges. Financial incentives for families with children, better childcare support, and housing assistance for young families can help encourage higher birth rates.

Immigration policies could play a role too. Programs to attract skilled workers, engage with the Armenian diaspora, and support integration could help offset population decline.

Economic reforms are equally crucial. By boosting productivity and supporting innovation, Armenia can partly compensate for a smaller workforce. Regional development initiatives could help distribute population more evenly across the country.

### Հրդրո կանանց և ընտանիքներին

While it's important to respect personal choices, the data clearly shows that Armenia's future depends on reversing the current demographic trend. Having children isn't just a personal choice - it's an investment in our nation's future.

Supporting women to balance career and family life is crucial. This means better maternity benefits, flexible work arrangements, and affordable childcare. Countries that have successfully addressed demographic challenges have found that supporting women's choices - both in career and family life - leads to better outcomes.

The decision to have children is deeply personal, but understanding its broader impact on society's future can help inform these choices. When women feel supported in both their professional and maternal roles, they're more likely to choose to have more children while maintaining their careers.

### Looking Forward

The challenge Armenia faces isn't just about numbers - it's about the kind of society we want to create for future generations. By understanding these challenges and acting now, we can work towards solutions that ensure a vibrant, sustainable future for Armenia.

## English Summary

### 🇷🇺🔗🌍 BRICS, 22,000 Sanctions, and Blockchain

***How BRICS+ is Reshaping the Global Economic Architecture***

The 16th BRICS Summit in Kazan demonstrated a significant shift in global economic power dynamics, with BRICS+ nations now representing 46.9% of global GDP (PPP) and 57.4% of the world's population. The expansion to include 13 new partner countries, including strategic economies like Turkey, Indonesia, and Saudi Arabia, marks a pivotal moment in the organization's evolution.

A particularly noteworthy development is Russia's economic resilience despite facing over 19,000 international sanctions since 2022. According to the IMF, Russia has become the world's fourth-largest economy by PPP, raising questions about the effectiveness of economic sanctions in a multipolar world. The summit also introduced concrete initiatives including the BRICS Pay system - a blockchain-based payment mechanism aimed at reducing dependence on SWIFT, and plans for a new grain exchange that could reshape global commodity markets by offering alternatives to dollar-denominated trade.
